results.title: Four Corners: The Moonlight State
results.creator_credit: Shaun Hoyt and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Despite denials by the Minister for Local Government Russ Hinze, Police Commissioner Terence Lewis, and Police Minister, Bill Gunn, widespread police corruption is evident throughout Queensland. Brothels masquerading as massage parlours with illegal gambling inhouse and drug trafficking are shown. Persons prominent in the criminal activities are named. This program was a major contributor to the setting up of the Fitzgerald Enquiry into Corruption in Queensland. Presenter: Andrew Olle. Reporter: Chris Masters.
Episode of the ABC TV program Four Corners, aired 11/5/1987.

results.title: Four Corners - Chief Justice
results.creator_credit: David Hardakre, Madeleine O'Dea and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Presented by Liz Jackson, this episode from the “Four Corners” series looks at the role of the Australian High Court in lawmaking. In a wide-ranging interview with former High Court Chief Justice Sir Anthony Mason, the main question answered is whether the protection of individual rights is better left in the hands of Judges or politicians.
results.description: Presented by Liz Jackson, this episode from the “Four Corners” series looks at the role of the Australian High Court in lawmaking. In a wide-ranging interview with former High Court Chief Justice Sir Anthony Mason, the main question answered is whether the protection of individual rights is better left in the hands of Judges or politicians.

results.title: Four Corners
results.brief_description: Four Corners is Australia’s longest-running investigative journalism/current affairs television program. It addresses a single issue in depth each week, showing either a locally produced program or a relevant documentary from overseas.

constellations_other.name: 1960s television
constellations_other.description: After its debut in the fifties, Australians rapidly became enthusiastic television viewers in the sixties as American imports started to be mixed with notable local productions.

constellations_other.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_other.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

results.description:
Four Corners is Australia’s longest-running investigative journalism/current affairs television program. Broadcast on ABC1 in Australia, it premiered on 19 August 1961 and celebrated its 50th anniversary in 2011. Founding producer Robert Raymond and his successor Allan Ashbolt did much to set the ongoing tone of the program.

Based on the Panorama concept, the program addresses a single issue in depth each week, showing either a locally produced program or a relevant documentary from overseas. The program has won many awards for investigative journalism, and broken many high-profile stories. A notable early example of this was the show’s epoch-making 1962 exposé on the appalling living conditions endured by many Aboriginal Australians living in rural New South Wales.
description_for_label:
Four Corners is Australia’s longest-running investigative journalism/current affairs television program. Broadcast on ABC1 in Australia, it premiered on 19 August 1961 and celebrated its 50th anniversary in 2011. Founding producer Robert Raymond and his successor Allan Ashbolt did much to set the ongoing tone of the program.

Based on the Panorama concept, the program addresses a single issue in depth each week, showing either a locally produced program or a relevant documentary from overseas. The program has won many awards for investigative journalism, and broken many high-profile stories. A notable early example of this was the show’s epoch-making 1962 exposé on the appalling living conditions endured by many Aboriginal Australians living in rural New South Wales.

results.title: Four colonial painters 1832-1896
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian eye”.
Launceston and the River Tamar (10min): An Australian landscape by John Glover. “The Conciliation” (10min): A “history” painting done in 1840 by Benjamin Duterrau. “Mount William from Mount Dryden” (10min): This landscape reveals Eugene Von Guerard’s Romanticism. “Lake St. Clair” (10min): Work by William Charles Piquenit. Rated: G

results.title: Four centuries of growing pains
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Balla, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
The film traces the origins of the British Commonwealth through four hundred years of history. It reviews how countries like Canada, Australia, India, and other continental and island territories, came to be added, and how each developed to the point of self-government.

results.title: Four centuries ago
results.brief_description: Mogul architecture reflects Hindu, Sarasenic, and Arabic influences. Fatehbur Sikri, a deserted city near Agra, was built by Akbar the Mogul Emperor in 1569. His architectural achievements reflect his philosophy, combining Hindu design and Sarasenic carving in the mosque, pillar and gateway to this city which was later abandoned.
results.description: Mogul architecture reflects Hindu, Sarasenic, and Arabic influences. Fatehbur Sikri, a deserted city near Agra, was built by Akbar the Mogul Emperor in 1569. results.title: Four back rooms
results.creator_credit: Peter M Sims, Kenneth J. Fairbairn, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: An indication of the research being carried out by the British Transport Commission in matters affecting transport and communications. Four examples of the work are given: design of railway lines; effect of counter currents on sea waves; siltage in rivers; stresses and strains in bus construction.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter M Sims, Kenneth J. Fairbairn, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films
